turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sweeney! You can't do that to me! Not today, of all days! Jumping Jehosophat! Oh, no, Sweeney... Well, I suppose so... All right. If you have to, you have to.  How do you like that? Everything happens to me -- with 365 days in the year -- this has to be the day.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sweeney.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Dead?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Not yet. Might just as well be. The only man on the paper who can write -- and his wife picks this morning to have a baby!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Sweeney?  Well, after all, he didn't do it on purpose, did he?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I don't care whether he did or not. He's supposed to be covering the Earl Williams case and there he is -- waiting at the hospital! Is there no sense of honor left in this country?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, haven't you got anybody else?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: There's nobody else on the paper who can write! This'll break me, unless --  Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You've got to help me, Hildy.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Keep away --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: It'll bring us together again, Hildy -- just the way we used to be.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's what I'm afraid of. "Any time -- any place -- anywhere!"

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Don't mock, Hildy, this is bigger than anything that's happened to us. Don't do it for me! Do it for the paper.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Get away, Svengali.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: If you won't do it for love, how about money? Forget the other offer and I'll raise you twenty-five bucks a week.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Listen, you bumble-headed baboon --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: All right -- thirty-five, and not a cent more!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Please! Will you just --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Great grief! What's that other paper going to give you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'm not working for any other paper!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh! In that case, the raise is off and you go back to your old salary and like it. Trying to blackjack --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Look at this!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I tried to tell you right away but you started reminiscing. I'm getting married, Walter, and also getting as far away from the newspaper business as I can get! I'm through.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Get married all you want to, Hildy, but you can't quit the newspaper business.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You can't sell me that, Walter.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Who says I can't? You're a newspaper man.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's why I'm quitting. I want to go some place where I can be a woman.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I know you, Hildy, and I know what it would mean. It would kill you.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: A journalist! Peeking through keyholes -- running after fire engines -- waking people up in the middle of the night to ask them if they think Hitler's going to start a war -- stealing pictures off old ladies of their daughters that got chased by apemen! I know all about reporters -- a lot of daffy buttinskies going around without a nickel in their pockets, and for what? So a million hired girls and motormen's wives will know what's going on! No, Walter, I'm through.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Where'd you meet this man?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Bermuda.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Bermuda... Rich, eh?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Not what you'd call rich. Makes about five thousand a year.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What's his line?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: He's in the insurance business.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: The insurance business?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: It's a good, honest business, isn't it?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh sure, it's honest. But somehow, I can't picture you with a guy who sells policies.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, I can, and I love it! He forgets the office when he's with me. He doesn't treat me like an errand-boy -- he treats me like a woman.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: He does, does he? How did I treat you -- like a water buffalo?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I don't know about water buffaloes, but I know about him. He's kind and sweet and considerate. He wants a home -- and children.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Say, sounds more like a guy I ought to marry. What's his name?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, I'll give you a hint. By tomorrow they'll be calling me Mrs. Bruce Baldwin.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Tomorrow? Tomorrow... as quick as that?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: The quicker the better. Well -- I finally got out what I came in to tell you.  So long, Walter, and better luck next time.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I wish you everything I couldn't give you, Hildy.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Thanks...

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Too bad I couldn't see this guy first. I'm pretty particular about whom my wife marries.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, he's waiting in the anteroom for me now.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Say, could I meet him?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do any good.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You're not afraid, are you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Afraid? I should say not!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: All right then, come on and let's see this paragon.  Is he as good as you say?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Better.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Then what does he want with you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Now you got me.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Nothing personal. I was just asking.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You wouldn't believe this, Walter, but Bruce holds the door open for me.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: No kidding?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: And he takes his hat off when he's with a lady.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: And when he walks with a lady, he waits for her!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Allow me.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I suppose I can't call this off without creating a scene -- but remember, it's your last fling.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: How do you like that? Here I am being nice to you and your sweet-heart and that's the thanks I get!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, I'll tell you one thing, old man, she never looked at me the way she's looking at you.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I might have, Walter, but you were never there.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Anyway, I'm glad you two are going to be happy and have all the things I couldn't give her. You know, Hildy is about the best reporter in the country -- and that goes regardless of sex. But all she really ever wanted was a home.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Here's luck to the bride and bridegroom.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What now?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: His wife had twins and he went out to celebrate and got as drunk as a lord. They can't even find him.  I tell you, drink is the ruin of this nation.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You said it.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: So -- Sweeney gets twins -- and Earl Williams gets hanged tomorrow.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: If he's nuts, why doesn't the State just put him away?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Because it happened to be a colored policeman.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: The colored vote happens to be very important to the Mayor of this town.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Especially with an election coming up in a few days.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, Bruce, dear. Don't you see? This is a trick to get your sympathy. No, Walter, I've been waiting for something like this -- but I wasn't sure when you'd spring it. If you want to save Earl Williams' life, you can interview him yourself. You're still a good reporter. Bruce and I will be on that four o'clock train -- and thanks just the same.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I'm an editor. I know what ought to be written, but I can't write it the way you could. It needs a woman's heart --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Why, Walter, you're getting poetic!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You see what I had to put up with? She never trusted me! You argue with her -- otherwise you're going on a honeymoon with blood on your hands!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: How can you have any happiness after that? All through the years you'll remember that a man went to the gallows because you were too selfish to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl Williams' face will come between you on the train tonight -- and at the preacher's tomorrow -- and all the rest of your lives!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What a performance! Bravo! Don't let him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an act!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What do you mean, only an act? Haven't you got any feeling?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, it's either an act on your part or a miracle on Sweeney's.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I happen to know Sweeney was married only three months ago. If he's got twins this morning, I claim it was done with mirrors.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But I'll make you and Bruce a business proposition.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: We're not interested.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young man. You let Hildy do this story for me and you can write out a $100,000.00 insurance policy for me. What do you say?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Now you're talking!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You keep out of this. Bruce, suppose you examine Mr. Burns in his office. I'll get my bag and go over to the Press Room in the Criminal Courts Building. You phone me as soon as Mr. Burns has given you his check. Then I'll go get the interview and you phone Mother that we're taking the six o'clock train.  And no tricks, Walter!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What tricks would I pull?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, nothing! Of course, you might cancel the check. Yes! Wait a minute! What would be his first payment on that policy?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What do you think I am -- a crook?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yes --- and that's putting it mildly! No certified check -- no story -- Get me?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: All right. The check will be certified. Want my fingerprints?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No thanks, I've still got those. Well, I'll step into some working clothes and hop over to the Press Room for the background on this yarn. It'll be kind of fun to see the boys again, too. Remember, Bruce, it must be certified.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Exclusive? That's great.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: It cost me four hundred and fifty bucks to tear it out of Cooley.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Never mind that. What's the story?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Never mind it? That's not my money! That's Bruce's money!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You'll get it. Now what's the story?  I'll have the paper send the money right down to you. I swear it on my mother's grave.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Wait a minute. Your mother's alive.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I meant on my grandmother's grave. Don't be so technical, Hildy. What's the story?!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, this expert Dr. Egelhoffer, from New York, decides to make Williams re-enact the crime --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, I'm coming to it. It seems the Professor had to have a gun to re- enact the crime with -- and who do you suppose supplied it? Nobody else but that great thinker, Sheriff Hartman!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: No kidding, Hildy.  Say, this isn't a rib?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, this is on the level, Walter. I'm not good enough to make this one up. The Sheriff gave his gun to the Professor, the Professor gave it to Earl, and Earl gave it right back to the Professor -- right in the stomach! Who? No, Egelhoffer wasn't hurt badly. They took him to the County Hospital where they're afraid he'll recover.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: That's great work, Hildy... Huh? Oh, will you stop worrying about the money? I'll see you get it in fifteen minutes.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: It better be fifteen minutes, because Bruce is waiting downstairs in a taxicab and that meter's clicking away to beat the band.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hold on a minute.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Walter! D-did you see --  -- that?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Yes. Where is he?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: She jumped out of the window.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I know. Where is he, I said.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Where do you think you're going?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I know, but --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You know! You've got the brain of a pancake! That wasn't just a story you covered -- it was a revolution! Hildy! This is the greatest yarn in journalism since Livingstone discovered Stanley for the New York Herald!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Wait a minute -- wasn't it Stanley who discovered Livingstone?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'd like to think.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I get it!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Let me get at that typewriter and I'll show you how a doll-faced mugg can write!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Whoa -- wait a minute. We can't leave Williams here. One of the other fellows'll --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That one -- how you gonna take him? They'll see him.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Not if he's inside the desk. We'll carry the desk over.  Give me Duffy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You can't take that desk out. It's crawling with cops outside.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: We'll lower it out of the window with pulleys. Quit stallin'.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Huh!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Get the lead out of your typewriter and start pounding out a load, will you? Snap into it!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: How much do you want on it?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: All the words you've got.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Where's some paper?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Can I call the Mayor a bird of prey -- or is that libelous?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Call him a love-child, if you want to.  Duffy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: How about the time he had his house painted by the Fire Department?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Give him the works.  Hello, Duffy, get set! We've got the biggest story in the world. Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post -- exclusive!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: For Pete's sake, Hildy, they're waiting for the rest of that story!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Okay, Walter.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: All right, Walter.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Listen, did you impress it on Butch that I want him and his gang here right away? You did? Every minute counts. All right.  Duffy's getting old!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Where's Butch?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, keep going! We want an extra out on the streets before it's too late!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Where's Bruce?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Bruce? Oh -- er -- he went out to get the tickets.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What tickets?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Railroad tickets.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Is he coming back here?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Didn't you hear him? Of course he's coming back here. Keep going, will you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Double-crossing swine!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You said it! But this'll teach him a lesson. He won't quit his paper without giving notice after this.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Tear into it, will you? Don't sit there like a frozen robin!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'm finished.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Finished!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Bruce ought to be back by now. Walter, you're not trying anything again, are you?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hildy, you think I could? After this story?  Here! You're just nervous.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Where's Mrs. Baldwin?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What did you do with her?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You been in a fight?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Where is she? Tell me!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Louie!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Don't tell me -- was she killed?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Was she? Did you notice?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: It's Fate, Hildy. What will be, will be.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What am I going to say to Bruce? What'll I tell him?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: If he really loves you, you won't have to tell him anything.  Snap out of it! Would you rather have had the old dame dragging the whole police force in here?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I killed her. I'm responsible. Oh- h... what can I do now? How can I ever face him? Oh, I hope he never comes back!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Look at me, Hildy --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I'm looking at you -- you murderer!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: If it was my own mother, I'd carry on! You know I would. For the paper!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Louie, where'd it happen? I'm going out!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hello -- hello...

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Gimme Western four-five-five-seven.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Who?  Hello, Butch! Where are you?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Mission Hospital? Gimme the Receiving Room.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What are you doing there? Haven't you even started?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Hello -- Eddie? Hildy Johnson. Was there an old lady brought in from an auto smashup?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Oh, for --  H. Sebastian -- Butch! Listen, it's a matter of life and death! Listen!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Nobody?  Morningside three-one-two-four.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I can't hear... You got who? Speak up! A what?... You can't stop for a dame now!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Is this the Community Hospital?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I don't care if you've been after her for six years! Butch, our whole lives are at stake! Are you going to let a woman come between us after all we've been through?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Hello, Max, Hildy Johnson. Was there an old lady --?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Butch! I'd put my arm in fire for you -- up to here!  Now, you can't double-cross me!... She does? All right -- put her on. I'll talk to her... Hello! Oh, hello, Madam... Now listen, you ten-cent glamour girl, you can't keep Butch away from his duty... What's that? You say that again and I'll come over there and knock your eye out! Hello?  I'll kill 'em! I'll kill both of 'em!  Duffy!  Mousing around with some big blonde Annie on my time! That's co-operation!  Duffy!!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Shut up, will you?  You sure? Nobody?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Duffy!!!!   Duffy!!!!  Well, where is Duffy?  Diabetes! I ought to know better than to hire anybody with a disease.  Louie.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Lafayette two-one-hundred.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: That dumb immigrant'll flop on me. I know it.  Can you imagine Butch doing this to me -- at a time like this?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Ring that number, will you?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Come here. See if we can move it.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Hello -- hello! Is this the Lying -- In Hospital? Did you have an auto accident in the last --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Will you come here?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Oh, I see. I beg your pardon.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: When I'm surrounded, with my back against the wall, you're not going to lay down on me, are you --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hildy, you just can't leave me out on a limb now. It -- it wouldn't be cricket!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I don't care what you say. I'm going to find Bruce's mother.  Oh-h...  I'm going out and find her!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Don't open that!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Who says so? I'm going to the morgue -- to look --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, you don't! Walter!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What is it? Here!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Yes! What are you afraid of Hildy? I dare him to move that desk out of here.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Wait a minute!  Let go there!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Murder, uh?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Hanging an innocent man to win an election!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: When did you deliver this first?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Who did you talk to?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Which ought to be about three hours more, I'd say.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Just until we can get out a special edition asking for your impeachment.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: And your arrest. You'll each get about ten years, I think.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: How was that for a tight squeeze?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Don't tell me you were worried!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Worried! I was petrified. Weren't you?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Uh-uh. As long as we were in there together pitching -- they couldn't lick us. Well, it's been a lot of fun.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: In a way.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I mean -- working together. Just like the old days. The things we've been through, Hildy.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: We've certainly been in some swell jams.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Remember the time we broke into the D.A.'s office, and copied Fifi Randell's diary?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yeah. What about the time we hid the missing heiress in the sauerkraut factory? Six scoop interviews!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Yeah - but that time we stole Old Lady Haggerty's stomach off the Coroner's physician. We proved she was poisoned though, didn't we?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: We sure did, but we had to go in hiding for a week.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: In the Shoreland Hotel. And our only chaperon was the poor old lady's stomach.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Don't remind me. That's how we happened to --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sorry, Hildy. I didn't mean to be making love to another man's fiancee.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's all right, Walter. It's as much my fault as yours.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Bruce is making the nine o'clock train. I told him you'd be on it -- unless you want to write this story yourself.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, if it's my last story, I'd like it to be a good one. But -- I guess I can't, Walter.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Suit yourself, kid. This isn't for me to decide. Of course, you could make a later train and still be in Albany tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yeah. I suppose I could. But, Walter --

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: He's going to have you the rest of his life, Hildy. Can't you give me another hour?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I don't know what to do, Walter.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Flip a coin.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: All right.  Heads I go -- tails I stay to write the story. Ready?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well -- what is it?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What's the difference? I'm going to write that story -- and you know it!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Don't touch me! I'm not doing it for you!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Then why are you doing it?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Because I'm a newspaper woman, Heaven help me!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: The greatest yarn ever written by anybody. My hat's off to you, Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: And what a way to quit. While you're still champion! That's the way to leave, Hildy!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yeah. Only -- only I'm not leaving, Walter.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What do you mean? Bruce'll be waiting for you in Albany.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: No, he won't. I wired him that I wasn't coming.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Where'd you wire him?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: On the nine o'clock train. That's the one he took, isn't it?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: It's awfully clear now. Bruce needs a wife who can give him a home -- and affection -- and peace. I couldn't do that for him, Walter. I'm what you made me -- a cheap reporter who'd give up her soul for a story!... Is that job still open?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Both jobs are open, Hildy. The paper -- and being Mrs. Walter Burns.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Thanks, Walter, but it's no good. We tried it.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sure, it was good -- it was wonderful! Only you expected it to be like other marriages. It can't be like other marriages -- we're different! We're a different world. Look at what we went through today. I wouldn't trade that for any honeymoon in the world. I bet you wouldn't, either.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: A fine honeymoon, with a murderer right in the boudoir! And that other honeymoon in a coal mine!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: That's what makes it romantic. Every other married couple goes away on a honeymoon and for two weeks the bride knows just where the groom is, and vice versa. But us -- you never know where I am and I'm not sure where you are. That's Romance!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, maybe I'd like to know just once!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hildy, if that's what you want, all right. We'll even go to -- how about Niagara Falls?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Niagara Falls! Walter, you don't mean that?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sure I do. And I'll tell you something else -- I'd like a baby.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Walter!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sure, I can't last forever. I want a son I can train to take my place on this paper.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What would you do if it was a daughter?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Well, if she looked like you -- Say! My brains and your looks -- that mightn't be such a bad combination.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What's the matter with my brains?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What's the good of arguing about something that probably doesn't exist? Look, Hildy, I'm proposing to you. What do you say?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Well, I'd like to be lady-like and think it over.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I don't want to rush you. Take a couple of seconds.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Now don't argue, Hildy.  How about it, Judge?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: That's what he said the last time. Don't believe him, Judge.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hildy, from this time on no tricks, no double-crossing -- everything on the level!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You're not fooling anybody.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: How about Bruce's?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Walter, you can't do that!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Sure, I can. Look at the policy I gave him!  "With this ring I thee wed and with all my worldly goods I thee endow: And thereto I plight thee my troth."

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Hildy, darling!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Yes -- 'Hildy, darling'. I'm just a fool. That's what I am. I know what it's going to be like.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: It'll be Heaven!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Sure, Heaven! You've probably thought up another coal mine to send me down in -- to get a new story for your paper!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: But, Hildy -- I can explain --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: You -- you!!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Louie, take this lady over to Polack Mike's and lock her up. See that she doesn't take to anyone on the way.

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: What's that -- what's that?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Are you referring to me, Madam?

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: You know you did!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Come on, Sheriff. We've got to get bail.

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: I was in here -- and they had some kind of murderer in with them. They were hiding him!

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: Oh, dear! Oh, dear!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You grey-haired old Judas!

turns.speaker: MRS. BALDWIN
turns.text: Let me out! Let me out of here!

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: Down Western Avenue. We were going sixty-five miles an hour. You know what I mean?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Take that mush out of your mouth!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Butter-fingers! I give you an old lady to take somewhere, and you hand her over to the cops!

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: What do you mean, I handed her? The patrol wagon was on the wrong side of the street.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Now everything's fine. She's probably squawking her head off in some police station.

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: I don't think she's talking much... You know what I mean?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You stay here. I'll find out everything.

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: Western an' Thirty-fourth.

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: Anything you want, Boss.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Beat it out and get hold of some guys.

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: Who do you want?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Anybody with hair on his chest. Get 'em off the street -- anywhere. Offer them anything -- only get them.  We've got to get this desk out of here.

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: You know me. The shirt off my back.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You got plenty of money?

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: Sure, boss.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I mean real money -- not counterfeit!

turns.speaker: LOUIE
turns.text: I always have both.

turns.speaker: DUFFY
turns.text: Walter!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I'm busy, Duffy.

turns.speaker: DUFFY
turns.text: Well, you're not too busy to know that the Governor hasn't signed that reprieve!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DUFFY
turns.text: And that means Earl Williams dies tomorrow morning and makes a sucker out of us!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: You're crazy. Where's Mac?

turns.speaker: DUFFY
turns.text: He's on my phone. He just called me.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: They can't do that to me!

turns.speaker: DUFFY
turns.text: Don't blame me. I'm City Editor in name only. You do all the hiring around here.

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Yeah! Well, I do the firing, too. Remember that, Duffy, and Keep a civil tongue in your head.

turns.speaker: DUFFY
turns.text: Here's that certified check, Walter.  I drew out my wife's savings, and if this isn't back by 5:30 I'm a ruined man!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Don't worry, Duffy, you'll have it back by five.  Thanks, Duffy. Stick around.

turns.speaker: COOLEY
turns.text: Hello, Hildy! What are you doing around here?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I want to interview Earl Williams, Warden. How about a little service?

turns.speaker: COOLEY
turns.text: No more interviews. Besides, a doctor's coming over.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Say, isn't this your twenty dollars?

turns.speaker: COOLEY
turns.text: I think it is.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I thought so. Come on, I'm in a hurry.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Cooley, I want to talk to you.

turns.speaker: COOLEY
turns.text: Hildy -- I can't. I'm busy -- I -- Let me up, Hildy. Earl Williams has escaped --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: There's money in it, Cooley.

turns.speaker: COOLEY
turns.text: I can't Hildy. It means my job! It means --

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: A lot of money.  Four hundred and fifty dollars --

turns.speaker: COOLEY
turns.text: How much?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Four hundred and fifty dollars. Is it a deal?

turns.speaker: COOLEY
turns.text: It's a deal. Let me up.

turns.speaker: COOLEY
turns.text: Let's see the money.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: First we talk. How did Earl Williams get that gun?

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: The newspapers! Sheriff, they're the scum of modern civilization.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: You said it!

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: They're always after me for interviews.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Me, too.

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: Of course, I sort of promised them I would give out a statement when I got through here. You don't mind?

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: Well, I don't know if that's ethical. You see, all statements are supposed to come from me.

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: We'll have to satisfy them. What would you say to giving them a joint interview? I could give them some of the psychological aspects of the case and you could give them the legal aspects.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: A joint interview, eh? That might be all right. We could have our pictures taken together, Doctor.

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: Yes, shaking hands. I don't take a very good picture, though.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: It doesn't matter. The publicity's the main thing.

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: Yes, I suppose so. It all helps.

turns.speaker: HARTMAN
turns.text: I don't know --

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: Come, come, Sheriff, lightning doesn't strike in the same place twice. Nothing's going to happen.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Are you gentlemen all through with me?

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry. I forgot you were here. No, Mr. Williams, we still have some questions for you. Sheriff, will you kindly extinguish the lights?

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: You know you are to be executed, Mr. Williams. Who do you feel is responsible for that?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: The system. But I'm not afraid to die, Doctor. I'm dying for what I believe.

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: I see. You realize, however, that you committed a crime?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: In a legal sense, yes. But not actually. Actually, I'm innocent. I didn't do anything.

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: Now, the Sheriff will be Mollie Malloy, in whose room you were. You will be Earl Williams. And I will be the policeman. Follow me, Mr. Williams?

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: So -- now I say to you: 'Earl Williams, you are under arrest!' and you point your gun at me.

turns.speaker: WILLIAMS
turns.text: Well, it wasn't exactly that way --

turns.speaker: EGELHOFFER
turns.text: Point the gun at me!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Well, that about covers everything.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Good. Now I want to ask you fellows a couple of questions. Did Earl Williams know what he was doing when he fired that gun?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Say, that's old Prissy Bensinger's desk.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: I know, I just want to give him a thrill.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: I call. What you got?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Three bullets! Any good?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Beats king up.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Who locked the door?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Just a second, Mike ---  Mollie, I got it!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Open up there, will you!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: All right -- all right!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Hey!

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Mollie, drop down here! You've fainted!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Kind of exclusive, ain't you? We got calls to make, you know.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Run down and get some smelling salts, will you?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Mollie Malloy -- what happened to her?

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Came up here -- had hysterics and passed out. I've been trying to get her to come to.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: She looks as though she's going to come to.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Give me a hand with her, will you?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Okay.  Up you go, Mollie.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: A fine bunch of reporters. Biggest story in two years and they're too lazy to go after it.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: It's easy for you to talk. You're retired. We're still working.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Better let us in on it, Mollie.

turns.speaker: HILDY
turns.text: Aw, why don't you let her alone? She's ill!

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: That must be the tenth alienist they've had on Williams. Even if he wasn't crazy before, he would be after ten of those babies got through psychoanalyzing him.  Gimme the desk.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: This Egelhoffer's pretty good.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Yeah? What did he ever do for his country?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Don't you remember? He's the guy went to Washington to interview the Brain Trust, and gave out a statement that they were all sane. It created a sensation!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Trouble is, when the Red Menace shows up the Sheriff will still be crying 'Wolf!'

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: What have you got, Hildy?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Well, a guy can win when Hildy ain't around.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Who's this guy she's gonna marry?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: She says she's gonna write fiction.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Well, if she's gonna write fiction, there's nothing like being a reporter.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: You guys wanna play some more poker?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: What's the use? I can't win a pot.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Boy, did you see her go?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Lioness Rushes to Defense of Cub.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: No, I tell you! Nobody knows where he got it.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: The Crime Commission has offered a reward of ten thousand dollars for Williams' capture.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Call you back.

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: So have we!

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: What's the dope, Sheriff?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Who engineered this getaway?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Say, Hildy, if I know you, you sound pretty anxious to get rid of us. Are you trying to scoop us or something?

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: Something smells around here. If you ask me Mollie gave her the story on how Williams got that gun.  Did you smuggle that gun into Williams, Mollie?

turns.speaker: MURPHY
turns.text: Oh, you two are pals now -- I think you're right, Endicott. Mollie did give her some kind of story.

turns.speaker: ENDICOTT
turns.text: I tell you, it's a screwy set-up. We better hold onto 'em both.
